content.description: Easy start. The crux comes between the 2nd and 3rd bolt. It is possible to bail to the left into a large crack which runs all the way to the top.
content.protection: 3 bolts. Setup a top rope off the two brackets on top (20 feet of webbing and 4 carabiners).
content.location: Facing the southern side of the pillar it is the bolt line on the left.

content.description: Climb to/from top of the Bridge Pillar; useful for setting up TR anchors. As difficult as East End Crash.

Short route two bolts. A top rope anchor should be built using the brackets on top of the pillar. 

  Super high ball boulder problem.
content.protection: 2 bolts. Setup a top rope off the two brackets on top (20 feet of webbing and 4 carabiners).
content.location: Facing the northern side of the pillar it is the bolt line on the right.

content.description: An easy boulder problem that has some heights to scare you a bit. Aretes off is a bit harder with the crux move before the top out.
content.protection: None; landing is not desirable so maybe a crash pad.

content.description: A line that traverses the lower pillar. Much like the traverse on the main pillar , the crux is near the northwest arete. Right to left is easier than left to right.
content.location: Start on the either arete edge and work your way across.

climbs.name: Shoulder Shrug
climbs.fa: Dj Wilmot (TR), then Jace Odhner (Lead, Nov 2016)

content.description: Shortest of the routes on the north face, which requires some nifty foot work. The easiest path utilizes the arete.
content.protection: Two bolts on route; cordelette top anchor

content.description: The highest problem on the lower pillar, which will almost feel high ball. Start and end where the angled blocks meet the normal stacked blocks and finish at the top of the last block. If you use the tops of the blocks beneath the top block, this is ~V2. If you do it without, getting the top should be the hardest move.
content.location: Right of the graffiti 'Truth is A'.....

content.description: Originally the western face of the lower pillar. This route has morphed into the route that follows the trim on the north face, west arete. The landing is promiscuous.
content.protection: Crash pad; if you fall, you might roll into the bushes.

content.description: An old bolt line that appeared to be missing its hangers. If done direct, the route will feel sustained. The crux is low and is difficult to bypass. Can use the arete to ease up the final moves of the route.
content.protection: 3bolts; can be set up off the top with a cordelette.
content.location: Right line on the southface of the main block. Marked by 6 holes that used to have bolts that went 1inch deep. 3 of which house the existing bolts.

content.description:
South face of the main pillar with the original send done left to right without use of the platform edge. Once you get to the platform area, you can use it or not. Much like the other traverses, using the platform edge won't change the grade since the meat of the route is towards the start and progressively gets easier towards the right end minus one slippery cruxy move.

 The name of the route comes from the (kinda) second crux near the big step, which can mess your ankles up if you botch the move. It’s often wet and your foot can easily slip off. If you have a crash pad, try to protect that move.

 Fight the barn door on the finish, grabbing the opposing arete with both hands.
content.location: Main pillar south face. Original start is on left arete. Initially, climb upwards two or three blocks till the arete begins to angle where a couple of good full pad edges will begin your traverse right.

content.description:
Beta intense start. Gets easy but dirty after first bolt. 

  Super high ball boulder problem.
content.protection: 2 bolts. Setup a top rope off the two brackets on top (20 feet of webbing and 4 carabiners).
content.location: Facing the northern side of the pillar it is the bolt line on the left.

content.description: Good rails everywhere, just need some strength to power through it.
No hard crux move like the left 5.11. Merely stout thin face climbing the whole way.
content.protection: Facing the southern side of the pillar it is the bolt line on the left.
content.location: 3 bolts. Setup a top rope off the two brackets on top (20 feet of webbing and 4 carabiners).

content.description: Support Column to the pillar; move left, move right, move up, move down, hell try doing a hundred laps around.
content.location: East growth away from the main portion of the pillar

content.description: One way to make these short routes longer. This linkup route starts on 'Dreams Killed by COVID-19' (left-to-right start), then traverses directly towards the 1st bolt of 'Stop Watching Television'. Finishes on that line.

The north face traverse. Original start is left limited by the moss on the short end. Left to right is much harder than right to left since the crux is towards the northwest arete. A majority of the route goes at V2-/V2, but of course there are plenty of ways to make this harder. Portions of the route are usually wet, but, if you want to wait, it takes two-ish days to dry after a storm.
content.protection: None; maybe bring a crash pad but the landing without is flattish and pretty soft.
content.location: The north face, inches off the ground all the way across.

content.description:
After rain, this route is the first route to dry off. Start on the second block from the right and continue the block line to the top. Can clip second bolt of 'Stop Watching Television'.

 Direct line goes at ~10d; if you use the arete, should be easier but a fall might be epic.
content.protection: 2 bolts; optional to clip bolt on ‘Stop Watching Television’ but it doesn't help much.
content.location: West areté of the north face

content.description: Linkup of 'Dreams Killed from COVID-19' to the original line of 'Don't Fret the Arete', starting at the very left (Northeast arete). An attempt to get some distance on these shorties.

The bridge pillars used to support a bridge connecting Schenley Park and South Oakland. There are seven bolted routes rating between about 5.9 to 5.11b/c. Many of these routes have been stainless steel bolted/rebolted between 2018-2020. The two pillars offer some opportunity for bouldering. The larger pillar rises ~25ft from the base, so call it what you want if you decide to climb the bolted lines without a rope.The blocks are cut stone about 3' by 6'. Amazingly there are a variety of holds on each route: jams, pinches, slopers, and of course crimps. Any route can easily be made more difficult if your goal of coming here is training. If you live in Pittsburgh its worth a trip.
